Title.evidence: Prehospital Plasma in Trauma: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: The unit of randomisation was the individual patient.

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included severe traumatic injury with high predicted mortality. The study was conducted in air medical transport settings.

Intervention.evidence: randomised 501 severely injured patients to receive either standard care (crystalloid) or two units of prehospital plasma followed by standard care fluid resuscitation.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to assess the impact of prehospital plasma on survival in severely injured trauma patients transported by air ambulance.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible for patients and clinicians, but outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 501 participants were randomised: 251 to the plasma group and 250 to the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The model identified 36 unexpected survivors, with a higher proportion in the plasma group (67% vs. 46%, P=0.031). The observed to expected mortality ratio was lower in the plasma group (O/E 0.56 [0.33–0.84] vs. 1.0 [0.73–1.32]).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported.
